DataElement.preferredName: Timed Up and Go Functional Test Performed Duration Second Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The numerical value that indicates the number of seconds that were required to complete the Timed Up and Go Functional Measure assessment.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Timed Up and Go Functional Test Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to the Timed Get Up and Go Test (A standardized rating scale developed by Mathias et al in 1986 which is used to test basic mobility skills in frail elderly persons and other populations such as people with arthritis, stroke, and vertigo. This functional test measures the time in seconds for a person to stand up from a standard armchair, walk 3 meters, turn, walk back to the chair, and sit down again. Scoring of this test is based on the average of multiple completed and timed trials) being performed.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Timed Up and Go Functional Test
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by Mathias et al in 1986 which is used to test basic mobility skills in frail elderly persons and other populations such as people with arthritis, stroke, and vertigo. This functional test measures the time in seconds for a person to stand up from a standard armchair, walk 3 meters, turn, walk back to the chair, and sit down again. Scoring of this test is based on the average of multiple completed and timed trials.

Concepts.longName: Timed Up and Go Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by Mathias et al in 1986 which is used to test basic mobility skills in frail elderly persons and other populations such as people with arthritis, stroke, and vertigo. This functional test measures the time in seconds for a person to stand up from a standard armchair, walk 3 meters, turn, walk back to the chair, and sit down again. Scoring of this test is based on the average of multiple completed and timed trials.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The period of time during which something continues._A unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour._A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Tests, examinations, evaluations used to determine a subject's status or response to intervention.
ConceptualDomain.changeDescription: Created initially to support CCR value domain for CTMS.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The period of time during which something continues.:The second is the unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour. Abbreviation Sec. is acceptable in non-scientific usage only.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: The period of time during which something continues.

A unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

DataElement.origin: DCI CRF:  Duke Cancer Institute Case Report Form
